section1.p1: The Special Rules allow people nearing the end of life to:

ul1.li1: get faster, easier access to certain benefits
ul1.li2: get higher payments for certain benefits

section1.p2: An adult or child is nearing the end of life when they are likely to have less than 12 months to live.
section1.p3: A person who is likely to have less than 12 months to live can make a fast-tracked claim for any of the following benefits (for which they are eligible):

ul2.li1: Personal Independence Payment (PIP)
ul2.li2: Universal Credit (UC)
ul2.li3: Employment and Support Allowance (ESA)
ul2.li4: Disability Living Allowance (DLA)
ul2.li5: Attendance Allowance (AA)

section1.p4: Clinicians can be asked to provide medical evidence on an SR1 form to support a benefit claim made under the Special Rules.
section1.p5: A clinician should complete an SR1 form promptly if they believe that their patient:

ul3.li2: as a consequence of that disease, it would not be a surprise if their patient were to die within 12 months

ul4.li5: senior specialist nurse (such as a clinical nurse specialist, advanced nurse practitioner or similar)

section1.p7: The Special Rules apply to anyone who may be nearing the end of life due to age or illness. There are no negative consequences for the clinician or patient if a patient who claims under the Special Rules lives longer than expected.

section2.p1: The 12-month, end of life approach used in the Special Rules means that the DWP is aligned with the NHS, where the definition of 'end of life' states that “patients are approaching the end of life when they are likely to die within the next 12 months”.
section2.p2: Clinicians are encouraged to identify patients who have reached the final year of their life and use a holistic approach to consider the support that their patient may require at this point. The alignment of the definition across welfare and health services allows clinicians to include conversations about financial support in wider conversations about what matters most to their patient, thus being more responsive to their needs.

section3.p1: It's important that you know about your patient's condition. It may be appropriate to complete an SR1 form:

ul.li1: to encourage your patient to see what financial support they may be entitled to
ul.li2: following a conversation about advance care planning
ul.li3: as part of an assessment about current social and financial issues
ul.li4: if requested by your patient or their representative

section4.p1: If a patient asks for an SR1 form to be completed, do not assume they understand the Special Rules criteria or that these criteria may apply to them. It could be an opportunity to explore their understanding of their condition, begin a discussion about advance care planning or document what matters most to them. All claims made under the Special Rules are processed in a compassionate and appropriate manner.

ul1.li3: whether the patient is aware of their diagnosis and prognosis
ul1.li4: date your patient is thought to have met the Special Rules*
ul1.li5: clinical features that indicate a severe progressive condition (for example, investigation results, staging if appropriate)
ul1.li6: information about treatment that has been received, is ongoing or is planned

section5.p2: *This could be the date of diagnosis, the date the form is being completed or any date in between. If you do not know the exact date, you can use the 1st of the month. Providing this information will ensure your patient is paid from the correct date.
section5.p3: You do not need to give a specific prognosis. Please use language that you would normally use when communicating with other clinicians.

section6.p1: Determining life expectancy in these circumstances is challenging. The following indicators may suggest that a patient is eligible under the Special Rules:

ul1.li2: rapid or gradual deterioration of an incurable or terminal condition
ul1.li3: worsening symptoms despite optimal treatment or management
ul1.li8: death is imminent, death is inevitable
ul1.li9: a high risk of sudden death with an underlying deteriorating condition

section6.p2: Patients may be eligible for the Special Rules when receiving ongoing or palliative treatment. In some circumstances, there may not be any treatment options available that would significantly alter prognosis.
section6.p3: Your patient's claim is likely to be helped if you include relevant information such as:

ul2.li1: no or poor response to treatment
ul2.li2: palliative care or palliative treatment in any form including palliative chemotherapy, immunotherapy or radiotherapy
ul2.li3: receiving symptom control and/or psychosocial support only
ul2.li6: treatment ongoing but unlikely to alter prognosis

section6.p4: The Special Rules criteria do not only apply to patients with cancer. They also apply to other severe, life-limiting conditions, such as:

ul3.li1: end-stage respiratory disease (for example, COPD, pulmonary fibrosis)
ul3.li7: end-stage neurological disease (for example, Motor Neurone Disease, Multiple Sclerosis, Huntington's Disease)

section7.p1: You can find information about general or disease-specific indicators, advance care planning, palliative care initiatives and NICE guidelines on these websites:

ul.li1: Supportive and Palliative Care Indicators Tool (SPICT™) SPICT_April-2019.pdf
ul.li2: The Gold Standards Framework Proactive Identification Guidance (PIG) Proactive Identification Guidance v7 (2022).pdf
ul.li3: Universal Principles for Advance Care Planning (ACP) NHS England: Palliative and end of life care
ul.li4: The Daffodil Standards The Daffodil Standards
ul.li5: Ambitions for Palliative and End of Life Care NHS England: Renewing our ambitions for palliative and end of life care
ul.li6: NHSE/I Delivery Plan for Palliative and End of Life Care NHS England: Palliative and end of life care
ul.li7: NICE Quality Standard for End of Life Care Quality statement 1: Identification | End of life care for adults | Quality standards | NICE
ul.li8: NICE Guideline for End of Life Care: Service Delivery Overview | End of life care for adults: service delivery | Guidance | NICE
ul.li9: What matters to you conversations What matters to you conversations

section8.p1: The DWP relies on the judgement of clinicians when they complete an SR1 form. However, a clinician may be contacted by a practitioner working for one of our clinical assessment providers if:

ul.li1: information provided on the SR1 form needs to be clarified required to help with a decision about the claim
ul.li2: an individual has made a claim under the Special Rules but has not submitted an SR1 form and clinical information is required to support the claim

section8.p2: Because we need to deal with these claims urgently, the healthcare professional will usually make contact by phone.

ul.li1: For UC and ESA, only an appointee or a person who has power of attorney can make a third party claim on the patient's behalf
ul.li2: For DLA, PIP and AA, any person representing the patient can make a third party claim on their behalf, even if the patient is unaware that a claim is being made

section10.p1: If you're a GP or GMC registered consultant, you can claim a fee for completing an SR1 form by completing a separate fee form.

section11.p1: You can return the SR1 form through the NHS Spine Portal, by email or by post.
section11.p2: This service is available from the NHS Portal on your desktop. You'll need an NHS smartcard to access the service. Once you have accessed the NHS Portal, click on 'Launch Digital SR1 Service' and complete the SR1 form online.
section11.p3: Once you have submitted the SR1 form online, you can download a copy and save it to your patient's medical record.
section11.p4: You can also download a fee form if required. This can be returned by post to:
section11.p5: To get an electronic version of the SR1 form and the fee form, you'll need to send a request from a secure email address with this information:
section11.p7: Send completed SR1 forms to form.e-sr1@dwp.gov.uk
section11.p8: The SR1 can be saved to your device.
section11.p9: Do not encrypt any part of the email. Any email that does not come from a secure email account will be automatically deleted.
section11.p10: No signature is required on either form for this method of return.
section11.p11: You can order a book of paper SR1 forms using this order form, which should be sent with a covering letter on headed paper.
section11.p12: Do not print the electronic version of the SR1 form.
section11.p13: Only original signed copies of these forms will be accepted by post.
section11.p14: Include in the letter a list of clinicians who may complete the SR1 form.
section11.p15: The order form and cover letter can be either faxed to HH Global Limited on 0300 373 0125 or emailed to dwp@hhglobal.com from a secure email address (see above).
section11.p16: If you have any questions about this process, call the HH Global Limited helpline on 0333 016 9656.
section11.p17: There are 2 options for returning the forms to us:

ul4.li1: give the SR1 form to the person who requested it and return the fee form separately to us, or
ul4.li2: post the completed SR1 form and fee form directly to:

section11.p18: When returning SR1 forms, please use a separate envelope for each patient. Do not staple documents together.
